seg.seg: I also, oh Ānanda, am of great importance beyond any doubt (?) for the Gautamid queen.
... I nursed her (Law-)body. She ... me from early childhood in every way ...
... I dressed her with garments. She (adorned) me with the ornaments of the world, ...
... I adorned her. She fed me with all kinds of food that had to be turned into bite-size pieces; I
(also) ... She washed me with waters of the world; but I (washed) her with the noble eightfold ...
... I (removed) the stain of the eighty-eight Kleśas, and in the same way I freed her from the continuity. She (decorated) me (with ﬂowers) of the world ...
... I decorated and adorned her with (ﬂowers) ... || There are no two sides of it, Ānanda. Of the advantage of the Law ...
... to make. Therefore, oh Ānanda, should this jewel of a cloth (be given) by Gautamī to the Community.
... also the Community. || There are, oh Ānanda, seven kinds of Saṃghālambana.
... (What) then are these seven Saṃghālambana? || The Buddha-god the teacher
... a gift given to the Community is called a Saṃghālambana. || The Buddha-god in the lead ...
... is called a Saṃghālambana. || A gift given to the Community of monks indeed (is called a Saṃghālambana.)
... given ... is called a Saṃghālambana. || With an undivided mind, ... (of a monk) ...
(if ...) one behaves correctly ..., it is called a Saṃghālambana. || Of nuns ...
(if ...) to the best of their capacity they behave correctly towards them, (it is called) a Saṃghālambana.
(If there are honored) those who wear the monk's robe around their neck, and among them there are after all pious beings, (it is called a) Saṃghālambana.

p.note: This fragment contains part of the third act of the Maitreyasamitināṭaka; an Uy. parallel is MaitrHami III, 7b24-8b16. See also 196-7.

The beginning of this leaf corresponds to MaitrHami 3, 7 b24, and its end to 8 b16ff. In the Turfan version, only a few lines are left, cf. 69-70, Taf. 22; the recto and verso in Tekin’s edition are to be reversed.
For oktuk okät pi cf. MaitrHami 3, 8 a8-9: säkiz on artuqï säkiz.

mā täm wäśśi ānant: these four words have no parallel in the Uyghur text, see MaitrHami 3, 8 a13ff. The new form wäśśi is interpreted as an adjective derived from wäṣt- ‘twofold’, and meaning ‘having two sides’, hence ‘ambivalent, ambiguous’.
Cf. MaitrHami 3, 8 a19-20; TA pissaṅkaṃ kälko el ‘gift gone into the Community’ translates the term Skt. saṃghālambana- ‘supporting the Community’, but is closer in meaning to Pali saṃghagata-.
The 3rd kind, cf. the end in MaitrHami 3, 8 b1.
The 7th kind, ending in : a1, cf. the somewhat different description in MaitrHami 3, 8 b12-17.
